explanation:
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 requires that pointers should point to const-qualified types whenever possible — i.e. when the pointed-to object is not modified by the callee, the parameter should be declared as a pointer-to-const. In the shown code, addresses of local fd_set objects (&rs, &ws, &es) are passed to urh_from_fdset. Whether a Rule 8.13 violation actually exists depends on the declaration/definition of urh_from_fdset:

- If urh_from_fdset is declared/defined to accept non-const fd_set * parameters but only reads from those fd_set objects (e.g. uses FD_ISSET etc. and makes no modifications), then the parameters should be const fd_set * and the current prototype violates Rule 8.13. In that case Agent A’s report is correct.  

- If urh_from_fdset actually modifies the fd_set objects, then the non-const parameter types are appropriate and there is no Rule 8.13 violation; Agent A’s report would be incorrect.

The provided snippet does not include the prototype or body of urh_from_fdset, so the claim cannot be confirmed from the snippet alone. Recommendation: inspect the urh_from_fdset prototype/definition — if it does not modify the fd_set arguments, change its signature to use const fd_set * for those parameters (and update callers as needed). This will satisfy Rule 8.13. Also note that urh_to_fdset must keep non-const fd_set * parameters since it populates them.

Conclusion: the report is plausible but not verifiable from the given code; you must examine urh_from_fdset to determine whether a Rule 8.13 violation actually exists.
